Fig. 1 Thermogravimetric analyses of ZnO and N-CNT materials with different N-CNT content. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 SEM images of neat ZnO (a), 1.0%N-CNT/ZnO (b), 5.0%N-CNT/ZnO (c), 10%NCNT/ZnO (d) and 20%N-CNT/ZnO (e). TEM image of Ndoped CNT (f). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) DRUV–vis with Tauc plot (inset); and (b) PL spectra of neat ZnO (i), 1.0%N-CNT/ZnO (ii), 5.0%N-CNT/ZnO (iii), 10%N-CNT/ZnO (iv), and 20%N-CNT/ZnO (v). Fig. 3 Fig. 4 (a) Concentration profiles of vanillin after 5 h reaction; (b) VA conversion (C), and selectivity (S) and yield (Y) towards VN production after 2 h reaction using the different composite materials; (c) maximum amount of VN produced as a function of the N-CNT content, the open symbol corresponding to the catalyst prepared by a mechanical mixture of N-CNT and ZnO, 5.0%N-CNT/ZnO-M. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 (a) Concentration profiles of VA and VN using N-CNT under dark and UV-LED conditions (open and filled symbols, respectively), and using undoped CNT (half up filled symbol) under UV-LED irradiation; (b) VA conversion (C), selectivity (S) and yield (Y) towards VN production after 2 h reaction using the different materials; inset b: HPLC profiles using N-CNT under dark and UV-LED irradiation after 8 h reaction determined at 230 nm. Fig. 5 Table 1 BET surface area (SBET ) and pore volume (Vp) of ZnO and N-CNT hybrids. Table 1 Catalyst SBET a (m2 g−1) Vp (cm3 g−1) ZnO 6 * 0.019 1.0%N-CNT/ZnO 9 (8) 0.064 5.0%N-CNT/ZnO 16(17) 0.115 10%N-CNT/ZnO 33(28) 0.162 20%N-CNT/ZnO 51(50) 0.216 N-CNT 228 0.600 * Within the determination error (±5 m2 g−1). a The values in parenthesis are the theoretical SBET estimated from the corresponding ZnO and N-CNT contents. Table 2 Conversion and selectivity for vanillin production using different materials. Table 2 Catalyst Gas phase Irradiation time (min) Conversion (%) Selectivity (%) TiO2-P25 a O2 30 40 9 air 30 17 16 Merck a O2 30 14 15 air 60 19 14 HPC3 a O2 60 16 13 air 90 15 21 HP0.5 a O2 60 11 20 air 120 13 16 ZnO b Ar 20 12 24 5.0%N-CNT/ZnO b Ar 20 15 27 a Data from [36]; TiO2-P25: TiO2 Degussa P25 (80% anatase, 20% rutile); Merck: TiO2 supplied by Merck (100% anatase); HPC3: TiO2 prepared by sol-gel (100% rutile and amorphous TiO2); HP0.5: TiO2 prepared by a hydrothermal procedure (75% anatase, 25% rutile and amorphous TiO2). b This work. Photocatalytic synthesis of vanillin using N-doped carbon nanotubes/ZnO catalysts under UV-LED irradiation Maria J. Sampaio a Anas Benyounes b Philippe Serp b Joaquim L. Faria a Cláudia G. Silva a ⁎ a Laboratory of Separation and Reaction Engineering - Laboratory of Catalysis and Materials (LSRE-LCM), Faculdade de Engenharia, Universidade do Porto, Rua Dr. Roberto Frias s/n, 4200-465, Porto, Portugal Laboratory of Separation and Reaction Engineering - Laboratory of Catalysis and Materials (LSRE-LCM) Faculdade de Engenharia Universidade do Porto Rua Dr. Roberto Frias s/n Porto 4200-465 Portugal b Laboratoire de Chimie de Coordination, UPR CNRS 8241, Composante ENSIACET, Université de Toulouse, UPS-INP LCC, 4 Allée Emile Monso, BP 44362, 31030, Toulouse Cedex 4, France Laboratoire de Chimie de Coordination UPR CNRS 8241 Composante ENSIACET Université de Toulouse UPS-INP LCC 4 Allée Emile Monso BP 44362 Toulouse Cedex 4 31030 France ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract ZnO synthesized by solid-state thermal process was combined with different contents of nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (N-CNT). The materials were characterized by several techniques including thermogravimetric analysis, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, scanning and transmission electron microscopies, and diffuse reflectance UV–vis and photoluminescence spectroscopies. The performance of neat ZnO and N-CNT/ZnO composite materials was evaluated in the selective photocatalytic oxidation of vanillyl alcohol into vanillin under UV-LED irradiation. The presence of the carbon phase in the composite materials (from 5.0 to 10 wt.%) revealed to be crucial for increasing the performance of the photocatalysts. The best performance for vanillyl alcohol oxidation was obtained using the composite containing 5% of carbon phase (5.0%N-CNT/ZnO), with an increase of 22% in vanillin concentration comparing to neat ZnO after 2 h of reaction. This enhancement in the efficiency of ZnO by the introduction of the carbon phase is attributed to the action of N-CNT as effective electron scavengers for ZnO, as revealed by the photoluminescence quenching, inhibiting the recombination of electrons and holes. Keywords Photocatalysis Zinc oxide Nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes Organic synthesis Vanillin 1 Introduction The interest in heterogeneous photocatalysis technology has been growing particularly in the field of water and air decontamination, energy production and CO2 reduction [1–5]. The outstanding capacity that a semiconductor material holds to oxidize organic pollutants in the presence of a light source makes heterogeneous photocatalysis a promising technology to provide green organic synthetic routes for fine chemicals with industrial interest [6–8]. The application of heterogeneous photocatalysis for organic chemical synthesis has been gaining increasing attention since reactions can be carried out at milder conditions of temperature and pressure and using water as solvent [6,7,9]. Zinc oxide (ZnO) can be considered a suitable photocatalyst candidate to substitute the benchmark titanium dioxide (TiO2), due to similar electronic properties, morphological versatility and lower cost [10–12]. The use of carbon materials in carbon/metal oxide hybrids have shown beneficial effects on the catalytic activity of this type of semiconductors by inducing synergies, or cooperative effects between the two phases, boosting the overall efficiency of the photocatalytic processes [13–16]. Carbon nanotubes (CNT), in particular, induce unique features when coupled to metal oxide semiconductors to form hybrid photocatalysts. Their capacity to provide large surface area, favors redox reactions at photocatalyst surface. In addition, the conductive nature of CNT may induce more efficient separation of the photogenerated electron-hole pairs. Moreover, due to the mechanical, chemical, electrical and graphitic structure of CNT, their surface chemistry is easily modified by reaction between the defects of graphene layers with adsorbed chemical species including oxygen and nitrogen containing groups [17–20]. CNT can also be doped in situ during their synthesis, and in that case the foreign heteroatoms are incorporated in their structure. In particular, CNT doping with nitrogen has been explored as an important route to improve the catalytic performance by providing additional electrons, which in case of the photocatalytic processes may hinder electron-hole recombination [13,21,22]. The increase in charge mobility obtained by combining ZnO with N-doped CNTs has also been explored in applications such as optoelectronics and in the development of anodes for high-performance batteries [23,24]. Vanillin (VN, 4-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzaldehyde) is a phenolic aldehyde widely used as a reagent in analytical chemistry, as a building block for polymer chemistry, as a pharmaceutical ingredient, as a food preservative and as a flavoring agent in food and perfumery [25–27]. Vanillin is the major component of natural vanilla, which is one of the most widely used and important flavoring compounds worldwide. The source of vanilla is the bean, or pod, of the tropical Vanilla orchid [27]. The world production of natural vanilla is minute, with less than 1% being extracted from the actual plants. Due to the scarcity and high cost of extraction of natural vanillin, synthetic routes have been used in the last years to ensure industrial need [26–28]. Currently, around 20,000 tons of vanillin are synthetically produced per year, most of it from the petrochemical precursor guaiacol (85%), while the remaining 15% is obtained from lignin [29]. Although the guaiacol route is highly selective to vanillin, it is fully dependent on petroleum derived compounds. On the other hand, the oxidation of lignin results in a complex mixture of compounds, resulting from side-reactions and incomplete depolymerisation [30]. Alternatively, biotechnological processes for the production of vanillin, involving the bioconversion of lignin, ferulic acid, eugenol, isoeugenol, etc. using microorganisms such as yeasts, fungi, and bacteria have been successfully developed [28,31]. Yet, the implementation of such processes is still far of being profitable due to the modest efficiencies, high costs related to the acquisition of the cell cultures and the need of separation processes for recovering vanillin [28]. Due to the great industrial importance of this type of molecules, the photocatalytic synthesis of aromatic aldehydes has long been studied [32–35]. The photocatalytic production of vanillin from different starting compounds (vanillyl alcohol (VA, 4-hydroxy-3-methoxybenzenemethanol), trans-ferulic acid, isoeugenol and eugenol) under near-UV (fluorescent lamps emitting at 365 nm) irradiation has been firstly reported by the “Schiavello-Grillone” photocatalysis group [36]. The authors investigated the effect of using different types of TiO2 and of the nature of the starting compound on the selectivity towards vanillin, the best performing system being that using vanillyl alcohol as starting molecule. Later, the same group reported the photocatalytic oxidation of trans-ferulic acid to vanillin using TiO2 and WO3-TiO2 catalysts under UV or visible light irradiation [37,38]. A pervaporation photocatalytic reactor for the synthesis of vanillin from ferulic acid has been proposed by Camera-Roda et al. [39], combining both the production and separation of vanillin in an integrated system. In the present work, we report the photocatalytic synthesis of vanillin from vanillyl alcohol, a compound naturally found in fruits and capsicum species, using ZnO and hybrid materials containing different contents of nitrogen doped carbon nanotubes (N-CNT) as catalysts under UV-LED irradiation. This is, to the best of our knowledge, the first report on the photocatalytic synthesis of vanillin combining ZnO-based materials (as alternative to the benchmark TiO2) with energy-efficient and low-cost light sources (UV-LEDs). An attempt to disclose the main mechanisms involved in the photocatalytic synthesis of vanillin under the proposed conditions is also presented. 2 Experimental 2.1 Photocatalyst preparation Zinc oxide (ZnO) was prepared by a solid-state thermal process using zinc acetate dihydrate (Zn(CH3COO)2·2H2O, >99.5%, Sigma-Aldrich) as a precursor. Briefly, a semiclosed porcelain capsule with a certain amount of ZnO precursor was placed in a muffle furnace under static air conditions. The temperature was raised using a 2 °C min−1 rate until 450 °C and maintained for 2 h, followed by another step using a 2 °C min−1 up to 550 °C. This temperature was maintained for 4 h followed by natural cooling to room temperature, and the recovery of the resulting ZnO powder was then performed. Nitrogen doped carbon nanotubes (N-CNT) were synthesized by chemical vapor deposition (CVD) in a fluidized bed reactor using acetonitrile/N2 as carbon/nitrogen source, as described elsewhere [40]. The N-CNTs were purified under reflux at 120 °C for 3 h with 50% vol. sulfuric acid (H2SO4, ≥99.9 wt.%, Sigma-Aldrich) in order to facilitate the dissolution of alumina and to eliminate iron particles (used as catalyst). Composites with different N-doped CNT content were prepared by introducing the appropriate amount of N-CNT in tetrahydrofuran (THF, C4H8O, ≥99.9%, Sigma-Aldrich) under sonication for 30 min. Then, ZnO, previously prepared by the solid-state thermal route, was added to the N-CNT suspension and stirred for 1 h. The hybrid materials were filtered, washed with water and dried at 110 °C for 12 h. The resulting materials were labelled as XN-CNT/ZnO, where X (1.0%, 5.0%, 10% and 20%) corresponds to the weight percentage of N-CNT in the composite material. 2.2 Photocatalyst characterization The thermogravimetric (TG) analysis of the materials was performed by heating the sample from 50 °C to 900 °C at 10 °C min−1 rate under air flow using a STA 490 PC/4/H Luxx Netzsch thermal instrument. Elemental analysis was performed on a CHN Perkin-Elmer apparatus. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed in a VG Escalab MKII spectrophotometer using a nonmonochromatized Mg Kα source (1253.6 eV). The specific surface area (SBET) was obtained from the N2 adsorption data at -196 °C in the relative pressure range 0.05–0.20, using a Quantachrome NOVA 4200e apparatus. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images were obtained with a FEI Quanta 400 FEG ESEM/EDAX Genesis X4M (15 keV) instrument. The N-doped CNT were characterized by transmission electronic microscopy using a TEM-FEI Tecnai-G2-20-FEI 2006 instrument at 200 kV. The diffuse-reflectance UV–vis spectra (DR UV–vis) of the materials were obtained on a JASCO V-560 UV–vis spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere attachment (JASCO ISV-469). The band gap of the photocatalysts was determined from the respective Tauc plot. Photoluminescence (PL) measurements were carried out at room temperature on a JASCO (FP82000) fluorescence spectrometer with a 150 W Xenon lamp as light source. 2.3 Photocatalytic experiments The photocatalytic synthesis of vanillin (VN, C8H8O3, 99%, Alfa Aesar) was carried out using vanillyl alcohol (VA, C8H10O3, >98%, Alfa Aesar) as precursor. The experiments were carried out at room temperature (20 °C), under natural pH conditions (pH ∼5.7), in a borosilicate reactor filled with 50 mL of a 0.5 mM VA aqueous solution prepared with Milli-Q water. The catalyst load was set as 1.0 g L−1. The suspension was magnetically stirred and continuously saturated with argon. An experimental run in the absence of catalyst was performed to assess the possibility of VA photodegradation. Selected reactions under dark conditions were also performed. The reactions were performed under UV light using four 10 W LEDs with an emission line peaking at 370 nm located symmetrically from the outside at 4.0 cm from the reactor wall. The average nominal irradiance of each UV LED reaching the reactor was 450 W m2. The suspension was irradiated for 8 h and samples were withdrawn regularly from the reactor and analyzed by High Performance Liquid Chromatography (HPLC) using a Shimadzu Corporation apparatus with a Diode Array Detector (SPD-M20A). A KinetexTM F5 1.7 μm 100 Å column (100 mm × 2.1 mm) was used with a solvent delivery pump (LC-30AD) fixed flow rate of 0.15 mL min−1. The temperature of the column oven and autosampler were set at 35 °C and 4.0 °C, respectively. An isocratic method was used with an equilibrated mixture of 0.1% v/v of formic acid:methanol (30:70) for 15 min. The VN and VA concentrations were determined at 230 nm. The VA conversion (C), and selectivity (S) and yield (Y) towards VN production were determined as follows: (1) C % = C V A 0 - C V A C V A 0 × 100 (2) S % = C V N C V N 0 - C V N × 100 (3) Y % = C V N C V A 0 × 100 where C VA, C VN corresponds to vanillyl alcohol and vanillin concentration at time t, and C VA0 and C VN0 for time = 0, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Materials characterization Thermogravimetric analyses were performed to assess the thermal behavior of the synthesized materials and to determine the amount of N-CNT in the composite catalysts. Neat ZnO, N-CNT and the respective composites were submitted to a thermal treatment until 900 °C under air flow and the weight loss determined. The results indicate a mass loss in the range 1.0–20 wt.% (Fig. 1 ) for the different composite materials, which is in agreement with the nominal carbon content used in the preparation procedure, i.e., the difference between the weight loss obtained for the N-CNT/ZnO materials and that observed for neat ZnO. These results were already expected since ZnO is quite stable under that temperature range, with no appreciable mass loss observed in the respective TG profiles. Moreover, since the preparation procedure consisted in a simple mixture of ZnO and N-CNT it is expected that the nominal weight of both phases didn’t suffer any change under sonication. The presence of N on the CNTs was confirmed by elemental analysis and XPS. From the elemental analysis, it was found that N-CNTs were composed of 6.1 wt% nitrogen, 76.9 wt% carbon, and the remaining 17.0 wt% being ascribed to the presence of oxygen. The deconvolution of the XPS spectrum of N-CNT (see Supplementary information, Fig. SI1) revealed the presence of 4.0 wt% of nitrogen distributed through the following N-surface species: pyrrolic-N (31%), pyridinic-N (29%), N-oxides (28%) and quaternary-N (12%). The latter, the quaternary-N species, should be favored in the bulk along with other ternary-N species such as amino-, imino- and to some extent some imido-, explaining the difference in the measurements. The results of the specific surface area (SBET ) and total pore volume (Vp), obtained from the N2 adsorption measurements, are shown in Table 1 . The SBET of neat ZnO is very low (6 m2 g−1) compared with that of N-CNT (228 m2 g−1). An increase in SBET of the composites was observed by introducing increasingly amounts of the carbon phase (Table 1). Both SBET and the theoretical surface area obtained from the contribution of each component in the composite materials were similar (Table 1), which may indicate that both phases are structurally combined without losing their former textural properties. Increasing the N-CNT content in the N-CNT/ZnO materials from 1.0 to 20%, led to an increase of both SBET and Vp , which may be indicative of the presence of higher amounts of active sites on the composite materials available for adsorption and/or reaction. Furthermore, taking into account the low SBET of neat ZnO, the observed increase in the total pore volume (Vp ) can be ascribed to the interparticle space created by the introduction of the carbon nanotubes, as observed by SEM (Fig.2 ). ZnO (Fig. 2a) consists mainly in 1D needle-like particles with uneven diameter along their longitudinal directions (0.5 μm–2.5 μm). Some spherical-like ZnO particles (100–200 nm) aggregated along the 1D needle-like structures are also observed. The SEM images of the composite materials show that the presence of the carbon phase doesn’t influence the morphology of ZnO particles, but contribute to their disaggregation. Due to the small diameter of N-CNT (∼20 nm) compared with ZnO particles, the presence of the carbon phase was hardly detected by SEM in the 1.0%N-CNT/ZnO material (Fig. 2b), with only some small N-CNT clusters laying on the ZnO particles being randomly observed. As the N-CNT content is increased to 5.0%, a better distribution of the carbon phase around ZnO particles could be observed (Fig. 2c). The SEM image of 5.0%N-CNT/ZnO shows the N-CNT well dispersed on the ZnO particles (inset Fig. 2c), providing a good contact between the two phases with ZnO particles being rolled up by the N-CNT. The composite materials with 10% and 20% N-CNT contents (Fig. 2d and e, respectively) show ZnO particle aggregates surrounding N-CNT clusters. These observations indicate that higher amounts of N-CNT lead to segregation of ZnO and carbon phases in the hybrid materials, which may decrease the interaction between both phases. TEM analysis of N-CNT (Fig. 2f) show a typical “bamboo-like” structure, as already found in previously studies on N-doped CNT [13,40], the nanotubes showing diameters around 20 nm. The optical properties of the photocatalysts were analyzed by DR UV–vis spectroscopy (Fig. 3 a). Neat ZnO shows the characteristic absorption sharp edge rising at 400 nm due to its bandgap transition. Moreover, it is noticeable that the presence of the carbon phase in the N-CNT/ZnO hybrids increases the absorption in the whole spectral range. Yet, Tauc plots (inset Fig. 3a) revealed no significant change in the bandgap energy of the composite materials, which was found to be c.a. 3.3 eV. The increase in the absorption of the hybrid materials was proportional to the N-CNT content, which can be attributed to the inherent light absorption capacity of the carbon phase, and may also indicate the possibility of surface electric charge mobility between the metal oxide and the carbon phase upon photoexcitation. The photoluminescence (PL) measurements of ZnO and composite materials were recorded at room temperature under an excitation energy of 3.64 eV (340 nm) in order to explore the occurrence of charge separation upon photoexcitation. The PL spectrum of neat ZnO (Fig. 3b) shows an intense PL emission band in the UV due to its high bandgap energy (∼3.3 eV), and less intense emission bands in the visible range, generally ascribed to the presence of site defects. The introduction of N-CNT produced a blue shift of the highest energy exciton band of ZnO, more pronounced as the carbon phase content increases, which indicates a good electronic energy exchange between the two phases. Initially, for amounts of N-CNT up to 1.0%, a small increase on photoluminescence is visible, with slight hypsochromic shift and loss of resolution in the 400–440 nm range, probably due to the emission of the excited carbon phase (acting mainly as luminescence impurity). Above 5.0%N-CNT the coupling of N-CNT with ZnO results in quenching of the luminescence intensity. These observations indicate that increasing the carbon phase content, N-CNT acts mainly as scavenger for photogenerated electrons produced in ZnO upon UV photo-excitation [13]. 3.2 Photocatalytic oxidation of vanillyl alcohol to vanillin The effect of coupling N-doped carbon nanotubes to ZnO was studied in the photocatalytic oxidation of VA to VN under UV-LED irradiation, using water as a solvent. A preliminary test, in the absence of catalyst, was performed proving the photo-stability of VA under the irradiation conditions used (see Supplementary information, Fig. SI2). Typically, heterogeneous photocatalytic oxidation processes are carried out under aerobic conditions. In fact, photocatalytic processes applied to the degradation of organic compounds, characterized as highly unselective reactions, are greatly dependent on the presence of oxygen as electron acceptor, which drives the formation of reactive species such as superoxide radical. Simultaneously, photogenerated holes act as active species for the generation of hydroxyl radicals. Previous studies report the photocatalytic synthesis of vanillin using TiO2-based catalysts under aerobic conditions, either using air or oxygen gas [36–39]. It was found that independently of the initial substrate used (ferulic acid, isoeugenol, eugenol or vanillyl alcohol), the production of vanillin is mediated by hydroxyl radical oxidation of the starting compound. Yet, due to the highly unselective nature of HO• species, the reaction proceeds also via aromatic ring opening to form aliphatic compounds such as formic, acetic and oxalic acids and ultimately to their total mineralization into CO2 and H2O [36]. Thus, the highest selectivity towards the desired compound is normally obtained at relatively low reaction times, the yield of vanillin formation being thus extremely compromised. In order to avoid VN over-oxidation by radical species, in the present work the photocatalytic oxidation of VA was carried out under anaerobic conditions, seeking for enhanced vanillin yield and selectivity. For comparison purposes, a reaction using TiO2 P25 was performed under aerobic conditions in the photocatalytic setup used for this study (see Supplementary information, Fig. SI3). The maximum selectivity for VN (merely 3%) was obtained at 10 min of irradiation, for a VA conversion of 56%. After that period, the concentration of VA starts to decrease due to over-oxidation into vanillic acid. Total disappearance of VA and VN was observed after 45 min of irradiation. In a similar reaction carried out in the absence of oxygen, a continuously increasing production of VN was observed during all the reaction period (see Supplementary information, Fig. SI3). The production of VN over time obtained using neat ZnO and N-CNT/ZnO composites with different N-CNT content is depicted in Fig. 4 a. It was found that ZnO can drive the oxidation of VA into VN, the maximum yield (9%) being obtained after 2 h of reaction, corresponding to a VA conversion of 51% (Fig. 4a). After that, VN started to decompose. Coupling ZnO with N-doped CNT, led to an increase in the yield of VN with increasingly N-CNT content up to 5.0 wt.% (Fig.4a). The highest yield of VN (11%) was obtained using 5.0%N-CNT/ZnO catalyst at 4 h of irradiation, with a selectivity of 24%. Comparing the results obtained at 2 h of irradiation (Fig. 4b) it was observed that a further increase in the N-CNT content, produced an increase in the VA conversion, but was unfavourable for the selectivity and yield towards VN. In the particular case of the reaction using 20%N-CNT/ZnO, degradation of vanillin starts to occur after 2 h of irradiation (Fig. 4a), being totally converted at the end of 5 h. This result suggests that the presence of a surplus amount of N-CNT, promotes the over-oxidation of VA to vanillic acid mainly, as confirmed by HPLC analysis (see Supplementary information, Fig. SI4). As shown in Fig. 3b, as the N-CNT content increases, a notorious quenching of the PL emission spectrum is observed, which is indicative of electron transfer from ZnO to N-CNT, thus increasing the yield and lifetime of the charge separated state. This quenching appears to be proportional to the N-CNT content, therefore for the composites containing higher loads of the carbon phase, there is a higher availability of holes at the valence band of ZnO, which act as active sites for both the oxidation of vanillyl alcohol to vanillin and for the conversion OH– from water to HO•, which then attack vanillin molecules producing vanillic acid. A volcano-shape relationship was observed between the maximum amount of VN formed during the photocatalytic reactions (highest Y) and the N-CNT content (Fig. 4c), confirming that 5.0%N-CNT/ZnO exhibits the best performance among the tested materials. A further experiment using a mechanical mixture of 5% of N-CNT and 95% ZnO (5.0%N-CNT/ZnO-M) was performed under the same conditions, resulting in a much lower performance towards VN production (Fig. 4). This result indicates that the procedure used for the preparation of the hybrid material may induce synergetic or cooperative interactions between ZnO and N-CNT phases, increasing the electronic interactions between both phases due to a more homogeneous distribution of them in the composite material. It is known that the presence of nitrogen groups in CNT increases the availability of electrons and therefore the polarity of the CNT leading to more stable suspensions in aqueous medium. These electrons can be transferred from N-CNT to free adsorbed oxygen, leading to the formation of reactive species that increase the catalytic activity [13,41]. Yet, since the photocatalytic oxidation of VA was performed under anaerobic conditions this is not expected to occur. Another effect promoted by the presence of N-CNT derive from their capacity to promote charge transfer. In fact, photoluminescence spectra of the hybrid materials show a blue shift for lower wavelength of the exciton band of the ZnO, which is an important indicator of electronic energy exchange between ZnO and the carbon phase. In addition, the notorious quenching of the PL emission spectrum observed for the composites with N-CNT contents from 5.0 to 20% indicates the presence of effective electron transfer from ZnO to N-CNT, thus hindering the recombination of electron-hole pairs. To better understand the effect of the carbon phase in the photocatalytic oxidation of VA, experiments using neat N-doped and undoped CNT were performed under dark and UV-LED irradiation conditions. In such experiments the amount of catalyst (only carbon phase) was set as 0.5 g L−1. For comparison proposes dark reactions using neat ZnO and the composite that showed better efficiency for VN production (5.0%N-CNT/ZnO) were also performed. It was found that N-doped CNT could drive the production of VN both under dark and UVLED irradiation (Fig. 5 a). Although, the concentration of VN was much lower after 8h reaction (∼0.01 mM) when compared with the composite 5.0%N-CNT/ZnO after 4 h of irradiation (∼0.06 mM) (Fig. 4a) similar selectivity was obtained when compared with neat ZnO (Fig. 5b). Under irradiation, N-CNT led to an increase in VA conversion, although the selectivity towards VN decreased due to the formation of vanillic acid (inset Fig. 5b). This result is in line with that observed when using the composites containing the highest N-CNT load (20% wt.), which promote over-oxidation of VN into vanillic acid (Fig. 4a). On the other hand, no VN production was observed either under dark and light-mediated conditions using undoped CNT, proving the importance of the presence of nitrogen groups to induce photoreactivity in the carbon material. Moreover, neat ZnO and 5.0%N-CNT/ZnO were also not capable to oxidized VA into VN in the absence of light. Heterogeneous catalysis using carbon materials in particular N-doped CNT under aerobic conditions using molecular oxygen or hydrogen peroxide as oxidant has been used for oxidation of organic compounds [42–45]. Nevertheless, the efficiency of these catalysts is attributed to the enhanced electron transfer of N-doped CNT to molecular oxygen or H2O2, leading to the generation of highly reactive radical species. Under anaerobic conditions, as is the case of the present work, the presence of electron-rich nitrogen species in the graphitic domains of CNT can increase electron transfer and electron density of CNTs, enhancing π–π interaction between the graphene sheets of CNTs and the aromatic ring of VA, promoting its conversion into VN [46]. Moreover, under irradiation, charge separation may occur at N-CNT surface, VN being produced by direct oxidation of VA by photogenerated holes. Regarding these findings, the activity of the N-CNT/ZnO hybrid materials appears to be highly dependent on the presence of nitrogen groups in the carbon phase, since neat CNTs don’t show any activity for vanillin production. Taking into account the previously discussed results, we propose the following mechanism for the production of VN from VA using N-CNT/ZnO catalysts under UV-LED irradiation: Under UV excitation, electrons are promoted from the valence band to the conduction band of ZnO and then transferred to N-CNT (Eq. (4)). Adsorbed VA reacts with photogenerated holes at ZnO surface, with subsequent hydrogen abstraction to form a carbon radical (Eq. (5)). The process proceeds via a second electron transfer from the carbon radical to the semiconductor with production of VN (Eq. (5)). Accumulated electrons at the N-CNT surface promote the reduction of H+ to H2 (as confirmed by GC analysis; results not shown; (Eq. (6))), considered a highly valuable reaction product. Overall, the present work shows that coupling N-doped CNT with ZnO drives the formation of hybrid catalysts with unique photocatalytic features for selective organic synthesis. Although both ZnO and N-CNT/ZnO show similar bandgaps, the higher surface area of the composite materials and the capacity of N-CNT to act as electron sinks may be considered the main driving forces involved in the effective production of VN from VA. It was also demonstrated that vanillin can be effectively produced under mild operation conditions (natural pH, room temperature and atmospheric pressure) and using low cost and energy-efficient light sources UV-LEDs for reaction activation. Moreover, the maximum selectivity towards vanillin achieved using both ZnO and 5%N-CNT/ZnO was similar but obtained in shorter reaction times than that reported in the literature using TiO2 catalysts [36] (Table 2 ). Although it is hard to compare the results obtained in both works, due to the use of very different reaction conditions (mainly the gas added during the reaction and the type of radiation source), we could achieve selectivity up to 27% in only 20 min of irradiation contrasting with the 21% selectivity obtained with TiO2 HPC3 at 90 min of reaction [36] (Table 2). Furthermore, the possibility of producing hydrogen simultaneously with vanillin synthesis can be envisaged as another advantage of using the proposed photocatalytic system. 4 Conclusions Neat ZnO and N-doped carbon nanotubes/ZnO hybrid materials produced with different N-CNT contents, ranging from (1 to 20 wt.%) show photocatalytic activity for the oxidation of vanillyl alcohol into vanillin under UV-LED irradiation. Among the hybrid materials, the highest performance was obtained using 5.0%N-CNT/ZnO. This increase was attributed to the creation of an electronic interphase interaction between ZnO and N-CNT, with the carbon phase acting as electron scavenger for the electrons generated upon ZnO photoexcitation. A further increase in the N-CNT content led to a decrease in the efficiency of the composites, which may be related to the capacity of N-CNT to promote VN over-oxidation into vanillic acid. The better performance in the presence of an optimum content of N-CNT was attributed to the presence of nitrogen containing groups at CNT surface, which facilitate electron transfer between ZnO and the carbon phase. The PL spectra confirmed that N-CNT may act as photosensitizers, as well as an effective electron scavengers for ZnO, inhibiting the recombination of photoexcited electrons-holes. Preliminary insights using neat N-CNT under dark and light conditions showed formation of vanillin, however in low concentration compared with the 5.0%N-CNT/ZnO composite. coredata.dc:description: ZnO synthesized by solid-state thermal process was combined with different contents of nitrogen-doped carbon nanotubes (N-CNT). The materials were characterized by several techniques including thermogravimetric analysis, N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, scanning and transmission electron microscopies, and diffuse reflectance UV–vis and photoluminescence spectroscopies. The performance of neat ZnO and N-CNT/ZnO composite materials was evaluated in the selective photocatalytic oxidation of vanillyl alcohol into vanillin under UV-LED irradiation. The presence of the carbon phase in the composite materials (from 5.0 to 10 wt.%) revealed to be crucial for increasing the performance of the photocatalysts. The best performance for vanillyl alcohol oxidation was obtained using the composite containing 5% of carbon phase (5.0%N-CNT/ZnO), with an increase of 22% in vanillin concentration comparing to neat ZnO after 2 h of reaction. This enhancement in the efficiency of ZnO by the introduction of the carbon phase is attributed to the action of N-CNT as effective electron scavengers for ZnO, as revealed by the photoluminescence quenching, inhibiting the recombination of electrons and holes.
coredata.dc:title: Photocatalytic synthesis of vanillin using N-doped carbon nanotubes/ZnO catalysts under UV-LED irradiation
